item.title: WE NEED TO SHOW UP IN NUMBERS FOR OUR KIDS!
item.content:encoded:
Denver School Board Director - Tay Anderson

WE NEED TO SHOW UP IN NUMBERS FOR OUR KIDS!
item.author: Tay Anderson

item.title: Community, In light of the circumstances surrounding the...
item.content:encoded:
Denver School Board Director - Tay Anderson

Community,

In light of the circumstances surrounding the COVID-19 Pandemic as well as many other realities for our students at this time, we, the Community Cabinet in service of School Board Director Tay Anderson, call for parents in DPS to opt-out of the Colorado Measures of Academic Success (CMAS) standardized testing in spring 2021. We also wholeheartedly encourage our Colorado State Legislature to pursue a federal waiver to forego administering an in-person standardized... state test this spring. Due to the significant hardships experienced by so many families, it would be difficult to determine whether test results were due to the quality of teaching versus the effects of the pandemic.

WEEK OF ACTION:

Over the next week there will be several actions that take place to educate parents on their right to opt-out of the Colorado Measures of Academic Success Test (CMAS)

Opt-Out Webinars (Tuesday & Friday)

February 23 and February 26 from 7 - 8 p.m.

Join members of the Denver Public Schools community for an informational session on how to opt your student out of this year’s state standardized test. The webinar will be available in English and Spanish.

Únase a los miembros de la comunidad de las Escuelas Públicas de Denver para una sesión informativa sobre cómo optar para que los estudiantes de las Escuelas Publicas de Denver no tomen la prueba estatal estandarizada de este año. El seminario web estará disponible en inglés y español de 7:00 a 8:00

Register in advance for this meeting:

https://us02web.zoom.us/…/tZMlc-6vqzsuHN1p-ox6x44VvilkfmGRl…

Car Rally:

February 28th, 2021 at 12:00 PM

Location: Manual High School

Join members of the Denver Public Schools community for a COVID-safe car rally to educate parents/guardians and students on their right to opt-out of this year’s state standardized test. We will have guest speakers, in-person resources for opting out, Board members, teachers, and school administrators that can assist in answering questions about the opt-out process via the Parent Portal.

HOW TO OPT OUT:

https://assessments.dpsk12.org/cmas/

Opting Out of Assessments
Families who wish to excuse their student from participation in one or more of the state assessments may do so by filling out the district’s opt-out application in Parent Portal from October to February 26. After February 26th, you may still opt out by scheduling an appointment with your principal or AP and request the Assessment Participation Exemption form to be printed off for you to sign (if your student has not begun taking tests). You may also write a letter and bring it with you to the meeting. If you have more than one child, you will need to fill out the form or write a letter for each child to opt out.

Your child will still attend school over the weeks that the assessment is scheduled.

See MoreThe Colorado Measures of Academic Success, or CMAS, is the state summative assessment for language arts, math, science and social studies. CMAS is aligned to the state’s rigorous academic standards and designed to gauge how well students are mastering the standards and are prepared for their next ...

assessments.dpsk12.org

Colorado Measures of Academic Success (CMAS) | Denver Public Schools Assessment, Reporting and Data Support

The Colorado Measures of Academic Success, or CMAS, is the state summative assessment for language arts, math, science and social studies. item.title: “People in the Montbello community wanted their high school...
item.content:encoded:
Denver School Board Director - Tay Anderson

“People in the Montbello community wanted their high school back, and that is exactly what we are doing here today,” school board member Tay Anderson said.

To make way for the new comprehensive high school, three smaller secondary schools in the neighborhood will close.

co.chalkbeat.org

Denver’s Montbello High School will reopen in 2022, per school board vote

To make way for the new comprehensive high school, three smaller secondary schools in the neighborhood will close.To make way for the new comprehensive high school, three smaller secondary schools in the neighborhood will close.
item.author: Tay Anderson

item.title: On the campaign trail I said we’d end the co-locations in the...
item.content:encoded:
Denver School Board Director - Tay Anderson

On the campaign trail I said we’d end the co-locations in the Far Northeast & on the West Campus, folks said I was crazy and it would never happen.

Now because of the work of Dr. Carrie Olson, Director Laurvick, Vice President Bacon, and I we delivered on those promises.

Montbello High School and West High School are coming back to the Denver Public Schools, this is the work that happens when when you elect folks to be champions for the community!
item.author: Tay Anderson

item.title: If students can play contact sports in Denver Public Schools...
item.content:encoded:
Denver School Board Director - Tay Anderson

If students can play contact sports in Denver Public Schools during COVID, I support finding ways to reinstate extracurricular activities like theater!

Great job to the students that came to our Denver School Board meeting advocating for us to do just this!

item.content:encoded:
Denver School Board Director - Tay Anderson

“Our Black Lives Matter sign makes us feel safe ... but we need to keep it up ALL year round!”

Today in our School Board meeting we heard directly from students at Mcglone Academy and from their podcast “The Voice of Montbello”
item.author: Tay Anderson

item.title: Question for folks that are against shortening breaks to avoid...
item.content:encoded:
Denver School Board Director - Tay Anderson

Question for folks that are against shortening breaks to avoid hot classrooms:

Would you support schools have the autonomy to call “Remote Heat Days or Weeks” for the days that are extremely hot in August?

** This is question to solicit feedback from Denver parents, students, and educators **
item.author: Tay Anderson

item.title: What would a school calendar look like that starts on August...
item.content:encoded:
Denver School Board Director - Tay Anderson

What would a school calendar look like that starts on August 30th instead of August 13th??

- 3 day Thanksgiving break
- 2 days less for Winter break
- Summer Break would begin on June 4th

...

It is likely that we will continue masking up through the next school year, so we must do our part to take away barriers that exist for hot classrooms.

August is the second hottest month of the year, which means that temps would be cooler in classrooms for the three days of school in June we’d extend the school year into.

I am in support of this!

See More
item.author: Tay Anderson

item.content:encoded:

& that’s on PERIOD.

Four Denver students who’ve pushed to diversify the curriculum will serve on a student advisory board for an innovative new U.S. history textbook called Black History 365.

item.author: Tay Anderson

item.title: I have decided to vote ‘NO’ on any proposed school calendar...
item.content:encoded:
Denver School Board Director - Tay Anderson

I have decided to vote ‘NO’ on any proposed school calendar that begins before August 30th.

Many schools lack the proper ventilation and are without air conditioning. Our students and educators deserve better than heat induced classrooms!
item.author: Tay Anderson
